results.title: Akira. Akira: production report
results.brief_description: This two volume collector’s edition contains the film itself and a 49 minute long report on the making of “Akira” featuring interviews with the director, the techniques he used and character profiles. “Akira” is set in 2019 in the city of Neo-Tokyo which is about to explode. A group of motorcycle-riding teenagers living in Neo-Tokyo tries to stop one of the gang who has run amok after becoming empowered with telekinetic powers in a government experiment. Technically spectacular, with colourful animation “Akira” is a must see for adult animation buffs.

results.title: Alcohol: how much is too much
results.creator_credit: Alan Capps, Frank Gardonyi, Ingvar Grimsgaard, Lou Lilly, Quartet Films and West
results.brief_description: An open-minded film which discusses social and physiological effects of alcohol. It is particularly designed for elementary grades. The film considers alcohol through such facts as its abuse as a drug, and its physiological effects on the brain and other parts of the human body. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Capps, Frank Gardonyi, Ingvar Grimsgaard, Lou Lilly, Quartet Films and West

results.title: Albert and David Maysles filming Big Edie and Little Edie in Grey Gardens
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.
results.title_for_label: Albert and David Maysles filming Big Edie and Little Edie in Grey Gardens
results.description: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
description_for_label: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. results.title: Alcohol in the human body
results.creator_credit: Felix Forsman and Fennada Filmi Junior
results.brief_description: A cartoon showing the impact of alcohol on the nervous system. It portrays sensibly, objectively and lucidly all effects of alcohol in the human body, and the problems these pose in our society. It leaves the viewer to draw his own conclusions.

results.title: Agnès Varda in Les Glaneurs et La Glaneuse (The Gleaners and I)
results.credit_line: Courtesy Zeitgeist Films / Everett Collection Inc. / Alamy
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.

constellations_primary.name: All about Agnes
constellations_primary.description: Belgian director Agnes Varda was the only female director in the French New Wave movement and is known for her long career across influential documentary and dramas, and for her trademark humour, curiosity and insight.

results.title: Air!
results.creator_credit: Paul Driessen, Pierre Moretti and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This animated short makes the point that oxygen is the stuff of life whether on land, in the air or water, but that it is becoming scarcer as man-made pollutants crowd it out. It is a film without words in which plants, birds, fish and, finally, man come to the same ‘breathless’ end. (Awards: San Francisco, Belgrade)

results.title: Alberta girls
results.creator_credit: Malca Gillson, Tony Ianzelo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The film follows the Alberta All-girls drum and bugle band at the opening ceremonies of the World Cup Soccer Championship at Munich, Olympic Stadium, and their tour around Germany.

results.title: Albert Camus
results.brief_description:
Albert Camus, born in Mondovi (Algeria) on 7 November 1913, earned a worldwide reputation as a novelist and essayist and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1957. Through his writing, and in some measure against his will, he became the leading moral voice of his generation during the 1950s. At the height of his fame, Camus died in an automobile accident in 1960. This documentary, made for TV, discusses his work and in particular his relationship to the Algerian landscape. Contains interviews with Jules Roy, Mouloud Mammeri, Francis Jeanson, Jean Pellegri and Pascal Piat.

Credits: Producer, Cecile Clairval ; director, Paul Vecchiali ; photography, Jacques Duhamel.
Cast: Julien Guiomar, Djelloul Beghoura [narration only].

results.title: Aladin et la Lampe Merveilleuse
results.brief_description:
A magician, famous for his tricks, is conjuring all the genies in order to find the marvellous lamp and become master of the world.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Gautreau ; director, Jean Image ; writers, France and Jean Image ; photography, Per Olaf Csongova ; music, Fred Freed.
Cast: Gaston Guez, Henri Virlojeux, Claire Guibert, Rene Hieronimus, Lucie Dolene, Fred Pasquali [voices only].
